data.title: New Orleans Jazz Fest's 50 top headliners from 1970 to 2019
data.meta_description: The New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival hits the half-century mark in 2019. The annual spring music extravaganza presents an array of jazz, gospel, blues, rock, pop, country, Cajun, zydeco,
data.text:
The New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival hits the half-century mark in 2019. The annual spring music extravaganza presents an array of jazz, gospel, blues, rock, pop, country, Cajun, zydeco, reggae and rap concerts played by New Orleans favorites and out-of-town stars. Here's a look back at a major star from each fest, plus other big-time visiting musicians and select local luminaries.

(Photo by Jennifer Zdon, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

(Photo from NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune archive)

1970 - Mahalia Jackson

Other big time visitors: Duke Ellington and his Orchestra

Select hometown faves: Fats Domino, Al Hirt, Pete Fountain, The Meters, Clifton Chenier, Sister Gertrude Morgan, Zion Harmonizers

A NOLA.com story about the first fest lists these memories: "Dixieland great Pete Fountain treating fans to a steamship concert on the river. Woody Allen giving an impromptu clarinet show at the Municipal Auditorium. Mahalia Jackson belting "Just a Closer Walk with Thee" in Congo Square -- then Beauregard Square -- with Duke Ellington closing the whole thing out. Just 350 folks attended the first, very modest and freewheeling New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Fest in April 1970, but with a lineup of legends like that -- not to mention Al Hirt, Fats Domino, The Meters and Clifton Chenier -- the local music extravaganza immediately became a quintessential part of Crescent City culture, heritage and lore."

(Photo by Steve Dipaola, the Oregonian archive)

1971 - Dizzy Gillespie

Other big time visitors: Movie director and clarinetist Woody Allen

Select hometown faves: Kid Ory, Pete Fountain, Professor Longhair, Zion Harmonizers, Babe Stovall, Papa Albert French and the Original Tuxedo Brass Band

Evening Concerts: From its beginning until well into the 21st-century, the Jazz Fest presented evening concerts at New Orleans' Municipal Auditorium, the Riverboat President, Saenger Theatre, UNO Lakefront Arena and elsewhere. The most popular guest performers usually appeared at these special venues, but they often performed on the festival site as well. Early on, the daytime, outdoor part of the festival was referred to as the Heritage Fair.

(Photo by Henry Grossman for Time Magazine, 1964)

1972 - Thelonius Monk

Other big time visitors: Nina Simone, B. B. King, Art Blakely, Dizzy Gillespie

Select hometown faves: Ronnie Cole, Sweet Emma

From Treme to Gentilly: The first two Jazz Fests were based in what is now Armstrong Park in the Treme neighborhood. Since 1972 the festival has taken place at the New Orleans Fair Grounds in Gentilly.

(Photo by C. David Batalsky, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune archive)

1973 - Stevie Wonder

Other big time visitors: Herbie Mann with David "Fat Head" Newman, The Staple Singers, B. B. King, Dave Brubeck, Taj Mahal, Howlin' Wolf

Select hometown faves: Pete Fountain, Olympia Brass Band

Renowned regulars: Some regional heroes appeared frequently at Jazz Fest. The list includes: James Booker, Irma Thomas, Pete Fountain, Dr. John, Allen Toussaint, Al Hirt, The Meters, The Neville Brothers, The Radiators, Wynton Marsalis and many others. In addition, a few visiting performers became Jazz Fest perennials. The list includes: B. B. King, Bonnie Raitt, Santana, Widespread Panic and many more.

Photo by Harry Langdon, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune archive)

1974 - Gladys Knight and the Pips

Other big time visitors: Herbie Hancock, The Staple Singers, Donny Hathaway

Select hometown faves: Professor Longhair, Danny Barker with Blue Lu Barker, The Wild Magnolias, Alphonse "Bois-sec" Ardoin

Fess at the Fest: By the Jazz Fest's 10th anniversary Professor Longhair had become an icon. The 1979 fest would be Fess' last.

Outstanding big time visitors: Ella Fitzgerald, The Staples, Roy Ayers, Chocolate Milk, Fabulous Thunderbirds, Dizzy Gillespie, Sun Ra, Lionel Hampton

Select hometown faves: Allen Toussaint, The Meters,

Ellis Marsalis, Jay Monque'd, Woodenhead, Rocking Dopsie, Kidd Jordan, Irma Thomas

10th anniversary: "The 1979 New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival has the potential to become the largest American music festival in history. It will feature an unprecedented eleven stages of simultaneous music, 42booths selling indigenous Louisiana cuisine, over 200 craftsmen demonstrating, displaying and selling their wares, KOINDU (a special African American tent of shared culture) and 10 evening concerts, all in a 17-day period with a projected attendance of 300,000" -- Jazz Fest program.

1980 - Chick Corea

Other big time visitors: Gil Scott-Heron, Count Basie, Dave Brubeck, Lionel Hampton, Sonny Rollins, McCoy Tyner, B.B. King, Taj, Mahal, Earl King

Select hometown faves: Fats Domino, Dr. John, The Neville Brothers, Allen Toussaint, Marcia Ball, Deacon John

Band you didn't expect to see at Jazz Fest: Chic

Was it ever purely a jazz fest? Fifty years after its founding, skeptics still criticize the Jazz Fest management for not sticking more strictly to the single musical style mentioned in it's name. But Jazz Fest has always included examples of other genres. In 1980 jazz fusion pioneer Chick Corea topped the bill, but the disco group Chic was also in the lineup and so was the poet Gil Scott-Heron, who was blazing a trail toward rap.

Select hometown faves: Chris Owens, Irma Thomas, Dr. John, John Rankin, The Radiators

Photo by Eliot Kamenitz, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

1987 - Dr. John

Outstanding big time visitors: The Band, The Four Tops, Spiro Gyro, King Sunny Ade, The Fabulous Thunderbirds, Leon Redbone

Select hometown faves: Fats Domino, Wynton Marsalis, Irma Thomas, Allan Toussaint, Ernie K-Doe

Someone you might not have expected to see at Jazz Fest: Kenny G

Heading to Gentilly: Though night time shows at venues such as the S.S. President riverboat, the Municipal Auditorium and the UNO Lakefront Arena would continue well into the 21st-century, in the mid-1980s headline acts began migrating to the Fair Grounds.

Other big time visitors: Erykah Badu, Roy Ayers, Allman Brothers, Lyle Lovett, Ani DiFranco, Sting, Bela Fleck, John Hiatt, Jimmy, Cliff, Diana Krall, The Temptations

Select hometown faves: Theresa Anderson, Allen Tousaaint, Better than Ezra, Neville Brothers

(Photo by Susan Poag, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2001 - Dave Matthews

Other big time visitors: Van Morrison, B.B. King, Widespread Panic, The Wallflowers, Wilson Picket, Dave Matthews, Frankie Beverly and Maze

Select hometown faves: Mystikal, Marcia Ball, Sonny Landreth, Galactic, Dr, John, Radiators Neville Brothers

Note: According to a post on the MTV website, due to the combination of the Dave Matthews Band and rapper Mystikal "the festival set a single-day attendance record of 160,000. This figure shattered the earlier record of 98,000 visitors set in 1998, when Jimmy Buffett appeared, a festival spokesperson said."

Photo by Burton Steel, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2002 - The Radiators

Outstanding big time visitors: B.B. King, Al Green, Paul Simon, Al Jareau, Maze, Widespread Panic, Dave Matthews Band, The Wallflowers, Max Roach, Van Morrison

Select hometown faves: Doug Kershaw, Rebirth Brass Band, Rockin' Dopsie Jr., Irma Thomas, Dr. John, The Dukes of Dixieland, Irvin Mayfield, Galactic, Cowboy Mouth, Pete Fountain, Fats Domino

Note: Like Dr. John, the Neville Brothers and (much later) Trombone Shorty, the Rads could be counted on to close out one of the Jazz Fest stages for years. The caption of this undated photo reads: "Musicians were covered by a tent, so there wasn't a single guitarist electrocuted during intermittent rain at Saturday's Jazz and Heritage Festival. Here, The Radiators appear before an enthusiastic crowd. Despite the on-again-off-again showers, all festival acts went on as scheduled."

Note: Springsteen's scrappy performance seemed to perfectly fit the first Jazz Fest after Hurricane Katrina and the 2005 flood.

Correction: Fats Domino was originally listed among the 2006 performers, but cancelled because of illness.

Photo by Brett Duke, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2007 - ZZ Top

Other big time visitors: Van Morrison, Richie Havens, Rod Stewart, Counting Crows, George Benson, Allman Brothers, John Mayer, Steely Dan, New Edition

Select hometown faves: Bonerama, Henry Butler, Pete Fountain, Jerry Lee Lewis, Irma Thomas, Radiators, Harry Connick Jr.

(Photo by Brett Duke, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2008 - Billy Joel

Note: Bennett has the distinction of being the only artist to both headline the festival and paint one of the festival posters, his 2010 portrait of Louis Prima. Bennett returned to the fest in 2015 with Lady Gaga.

(Photo by John McCusker, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2010 - Simon and Garfunkel

Other big time visitors: Pearl Jam, Drake, George Clinton, Lionel Richie, Black Crows, Anita Baker, Gov't Mule, Elvis Costello, Blues Traveler, Jose Feliciano, Jeff Beck

Select hometown faves: Dr. John, Funky Meters, Neville Brothers, Radiators, Eillis Marsalis

Note: According to Robert Hilburn's biography "Paul Simon: A Life," the 2010 Jazz Fest was the last time the quarrelsome folk-rock superstars performed as a duo. Read: "Did Simon and Garfunkel's very last show happen in New Orleans?"

(Photo by Chris Granger, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2015 - Elton John

Other big time visitors: The Who, Ryan Adams, Pitbull, Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga, Chicago, No Doubt, Ed Sheeran, Tedeschi Trucks Band

Select hometown faves: Royal Teeth, Brass-A-Holics, Revivalists, Dirty Dozen Brass Bands, Radiators

As NOLA.com reported: "Saturday certainly felt like one of the biggest days in recent Jazz Fest history. Whatever the capacity of the Acura Stage field - 50,000? 60,000? - it was at maximum capacity for Elton John. This was no surprise: Sunny weather plus Saturday plus a legacy artist with a vast catalog of songs most people on the planet know by heart will equal an enormous turnout every time."

(Photo by Brett Duke, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2018 - Aerosmith

Other big time visitors: Anita Baker, Steel Pulse, Khalid, Rod Stewart, David Byrne, Lyle Lovett, Toots and Maytals, Beck, Cage the Elephant, Steve Miller

Select hometown faves: Big Freedia, Tank and the Bangas, Sonny Landreth, Doug Kershaw, Aaron Neville, The Radiators

(Photo by Doug MacCash, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

2019 - Katy Perry

Other big time visitors: Alanis Morsette, Doobie Brothers, Leon Bridges, Van Morrison, Johnny Rivers, Tom Jones, Mavis Staples, Gladys Knight, Los Lobos, Pit Bull, Diana Ross

Select hometown faves: Boyfriend, Big Freedia, Tank and the Bangas, The Revivalists, Chris Owens, Hurray for the Riff Raff, Nathan and the Zydeco Cha Chas

(Photo by Michel Euler, AP)

The year of the cancellations

The 50th anniversary Jazz Fest may be remembered for the performers who were unable to appear. The Rolling Stones were expected to appear on May 2, but canceled when vocalist Mick Jagger required heart valve surgery.

The Stones were replaced by Fleetwood Mac, which was forced to bow out in order for vocalist Stevie Nicks to recover from the flu.

Fleetwood Mac was then replaced by Widespread Panic.

Please read: "Jazz Fest stars should all cover Mick Jagger, Stevie Nicks and Jerry Lee Lewis songs"

Photo of Sheryl Crow by Michael DeMocker, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

Who decided?

Many thanks to the Jazz Fest archive for providing access to all of the annual festival programs.

Since the festival usually spans seven days, with innumerable acts on several stages, at various sites, it was difficult to decide exactly who was THE headliner for any given year. In creating our list of Jazz Fest's biggest stars from 1970 to 2019, we avoided duplications and tried to choose shows that implied the variety found at the festival.

(Photo of festival closer Trombone Shorty by David Grunfeld, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune)

Doug MacCash

has the best job in the world, covering art, music and culture in New Orleans. Contact him via email at dmaccash@nola.com. Follow him on Instagram at dougmaccash, on Twitter at Doug MacCashand on Facebook at Douglas James MacCash. As always, please add your point of view to the comment stream.
